description: Above 6 months: Children need a variety of foods to meet their nutrition needs.
title: Above 6 months: Children need a variety of foods to meet their nutrition needs
content:
In addition to breastmilk, children above 6 months need vegetables and fruits, meat, poultry, fish, eggs and dairy products to support their growth and development. 

 - **Staple food:** cereals (rice, wheat, maize, millet, quinoa), roots
   (cassava, yam, potatoes) and starchy fruits (plantain and
   breadfruit).

 - **High-protein foods:** red meat, poultry, fish, liver and eggs (can be
   given as often as possible).

 - **Dairy products:** cheese, yogurt, curds and dried milk (which can be
   mixed with other foods, such as cooked porridge). These are better
   than raw animal milk which is harder for children to digest. Dairy
   products are good choices in the second six months of a breastfed
   child's life.

 - **Vegetables:** green leafy and orange-coloured vegetables, such as
   spinach, broccoli, chard, carrots, pumpkins and sweet potatoes (which
   provide vitamins).

 - **Pulse:** chickpeas, lentils, cowpeas, black-eyed peas, kidney beans and
   lima beans (to add variety and provide protein, energy and some
   iron).

 - **Oils:** rapeseed oil, soy oil, red palm oil, butter or margarine.

 - **Seeds:** groundnut paste, other nut pastes and soaked or germinated
   seeds, such as pumpkin, sunflower, melon or sesame seeds (for energy
   and some vitamins).


Do not give children food that may cause choking. Foods to be avoided are nuts, grapes, raw carrots and other foods that have a shape and/or consistency that may cause them to become lodged in the child's throat.

A trained health worker can advise the parent about foods that provide the most nutrients and which supplements to use.
